10-29.text: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly being used in education to personalize learning, support teachers, and improve student outcomes. AI systems can tailor educational content to individual student needs, providing real-time feedback and identifying areas where students may need additional support. AI is also being used to automate administrative tasks such as grading tests and managing academic records, freeing up time for teachers to focus on teaching. AI is also making it easier to access high-quality educational resources regardless of geographic location through online learning platforms. However, the integration of AI into education raises questions about privacy, bias in algorithms, and the role of the teacher. It is crucial to ensure that AI is used ethically and equitably, complementing human teaching and promoting inclusion and accessibility in education.

10-30.text: Sustainable transport is becoming a global priority as cities face challenges such as congestion, air pollution and climate change. Sustainable transport solutions include developing efficient public transport systems, promoting the use of bicycles and electric vehicles, and urban planning that encourages walking and active mobility. Cities such as Copenhagen and Amsterdam are examples of successful implementation of bicycle infrastructure, while countries such as Norway are leading the way in the adoption of electric vehicles. In addition, emerging technologies such as autonomous vehicles and ride-sharing have the potential to transform urban mobility, making it more efficient and accessible. However, the transition to sustainable transport faces challenges such as the need for significant infrastructure investments, changing cultural behaviors and ensuring accessibility for all populations. Sustainable transport is essential to improving the quality of life in cities and reducing the global carbon footprint.

10-31.text: Electronic health records (EHRs) are transforming the way health data is managed and shared, providing healthcare professionals with fast and accurate access to patient information. EHRs allow doctors, nurses, and other healthcare professionals to access a patient’s medical history in real time, which can improve the quality of care, reduce medical errors, and facilitate care coordination between different providers. Additionally, EHRs can be integrated with artificial intelligence systems to aid in the diagnosis and management of chronic diseases. However, implementing EHRs also faces challenges, such as data privacy, interoperability between different systems, and resistance to change among healthcare professionals. Ensuring the security and confidentiality of patient data is critical to the success of EHRs, which have the potential to transform medical practice and improve health outcomes.

11-1.text: The development of alternative materials is gaining prominence as a response to environmental and sustainability concerns, replacing traditional materials with negative impacts, such as plastics and cement. Innovative materials such as bioplastics made from agricultural waste, low-carbon concrete and engineered wood are being developed to reduce carbon emissions, increase energy efficiency and promote the circular economy. In addition, research into nanomaterials and smart materials is opening up new possibilities for applications in construction, packaging and electronics. These materials not only offer environmental benefits but can also improve the performance and durability of end products. However, the transition to alternative materials faces challenges, such as production cost, scalability and the need for clear regulatory standards. Successful adoption of alternative materials will be crucial to building a more sustainable and resilient economy.

11-2.text: Telehealth, or digital health, is revolutionizing access to healthcare by enabling patients to consult with doctors and receive treatment remotely using communication technologies. This model of care has proven especially valuable in rural and isolated areas where access to specialists is limited, and during pandemics such as COVID-19, when in-person visits can pose risks. Telehealth encompasses a wide range of services, from video consultations and remote patient monitoring to prescription delivery and health education. In addition, telehealth can improve healthcare system efficiency by reducing wait times and operating costs. However, challenges such as privacy protection, quality of care, and equity in access to technology still need to be addressed for telehealth to become an integral and effective part of global healthcare systems. Telehealth represents a significant transformation in the way healthcare is delivered and received, with the potential to improve accessibility and quality of care for millions of people.

11-3.text: Smart infrastructure is reshaping the way cities are planned, built and managed, using digital technologies to increase efficiency, sustainability and urban resilience. Smart energy, water and transport management systems enable more efficient use of resources and reduce waste, while real-time sensors and communication networks monitor the health of bridges, roads and buildings, anticipating the need for repairs and maintenance. In addition, smart infrastructure facilitates the integration of renewable energy into the electricity grid and the development of multimodal transport networks that efficiently connect bicycles, buses, trains and electric vehicles. The adoption of smart infrastructure is essential to address the challenges of 21st century cities, such as population growth, climate change and rapid urbanization. However, its implementation requires significant investment, clear regulations and collaboration between the public and private sectors to ensure that the benefits are widely distributed and that cities become more livable and sustainable for all.

11-4.text: Adaptation to climate change is an urgent need to mitigate the negative impacts that are already being felt around the world, such as extreme weather events, sea level rise and changes in precipitation patterns. Adaptation involves a range of strategies, including building resilient infrastructure, implementing early warning systems for natural disasters, protecting and restoring natural ecosystems and promoting sustainable agricultural practices. In addition, climate adaptation policies seek to protect the most vulnerable populations, who are often the most affected by climate change, and to ensure that economic development is compatible with environmental sustainability. Adaptation also requires the mobilization of significant financial resources, from both public and private sources, to finance infrastructure projects and research and development of new technologies. Climate adaptation is a critical component of the global response to climate change and is essential to protect lives, economies and ecosystems.

11-5.text: Ethical supply chains are becoming a priority for companies and consumers concerned about the social and environmental impacts of global operations. An ethical supply chain ensures that products are manufactured under safe and fair conditions, without worker exploitation, child labor, or environmental degradation. Companies are adopting due diligence practices, independent audits, and certifications such as Fair Trade to ensure that their supply chains meet high ethical standards. In addition, supply chain transparency, including the traceability of materials from source to final product, is becoming increasingly important to consumers and investors. Implementing ethical supply chains faces challenges such as the complexity of global supply chains, the variability of regulations across countries, and the cost of monitoring and verification. However, companies that adopt ethical practices not only promote social justice and environmental sustainability, but also build trust and loyalty among conscious consumers, creating long-term value.

11-6.text: Sustainable fashion is emerging as a response to growing criticism about the environmental and social impacts of the fashion industry, which is known for its contribution to waste, pollution and poor working conditions. Sustainable fashion encompasses a wide range of practices, from the use of eco-friendly materials such as organic cotton and recycled fabrics to the development of cleaner, more efficient production processes. In addition, the concept of circular fashion, which promotes the reuse and recycling of clothing, is gaining traction, with brands encouraging the return of used items and the design of durable, timeless clothing. Supply chain transparency and fair trade are also key aspects of sustainable fashion, ensuring that workers are treated fairly and that environmental impacts are minimized. While sustainable fashion still faces challenges, such as cost and the need for changes in consumer behavior, it represents an important step towards a more responsible and conscious fashion industry.

11-7.text: Climate change mitigation involves global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and limit global warming to safe levels, as set out in the Paris Agreement. Mitigation strategies include transitioning to renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, promoting energy efficiency, protecting forests and other carbon sinks, and developing carbon capture and storage technologies. In addition, mitigation requires changes in land use, agriculture, and transportation systems to reduce emissions and increase resilience. Mitigation is essential to avoid the worst impacts of climate change, but it also faces significant challenges, including continued dependence on fossil fuels, political resistance, and the need for massive investment. International cooperation, climate finance, and private sector engagement are key to achieving mitigation goals and ensuring a sustainable future for future generations.

11-8.text: Social entrepreneurship is emerging as a powerful force for change, combining business innovation with a mission to solve social and environmental problems. Social entrepreneurs create sustainable businesses that focus on the well-being of communities, promote social inclusion, and seek solutions to issues such as poverty, health, education, and the environment. Unlike traditional businesses, the primary focus of social entrepreneurship is to generate positive impact rather than maximize profits. However, financial sustainability is crucial to ensuring that these ventures can continue to operate and expand their reach. Successful examples include microfinance to support small entrepreneurs in developing countries, accessible education through digital technologies, and recycling initiatives that employ vulnerable communities. Supporting social entrepreneurs through funding, mentoring networks, and supportive public policies is essential to scaling their innovations and contributing to more equitable and sustainable development.

11-9.text: Population ageing is one of the most significant demographic challenges of the 21st century, with profound implications for the economy, public health and social welfare. As life expectancy increases and birth rates decline, many countries face an ageing population, which may lead to greater demand for health care, long-term care services and sustainable retirement systems. Health innovations such as personalized medicine, telemedicine and assistive robotics are being developed to improve the quality of life of older people and reduce the burden on health systems. In addition, active ageing policies, which promote the social and economic participation of older people, are key to addressing the challenges of population ageing. However, adapting to an ageing population also requires changes in urban infrastructure, the labour market and social policies. The response to population ageing must be comprehensive, involving collaboration between governments, the private sector and civil society to ensure that all individuals can age with dignity and security.

11-10.text: Access to adequate sanitation and safe water is fundamental to public health, economic development and human dignity. Yet millions of people around the world still lack these basic services, contributing to the spread of disease, environmental degradation and the perpetuation of poverty. Global initiatives are focused on expanding access to clean water and sanitation by building infrastructure such as water distribution systems, sewage systems and treatment plants, as well as promoting personal hygiene. Innovative technologies such as portable water filters, dry toilets and low-cost desalination are helping to address sanitation challenges in both rural and urban areas. In addition, hygiene education and community participation are essential to ensure that sanitation solutions are sustainable and adapted to local needs. Improving access to water and sanitation is crucial to achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals and ensuring healthy lives for all.

11-11.text: Impact investing is an investment approach that seeks to generate measurable social and environmental benefits in addition to financial returns. Unlike traditional investments, which focus exclusively on profit, impact investors seek to support companies, organizations, and projects that advance social well-being, environmental sustainability, and inclusive development. This type of investment is growing rapidly as individual investors, investment funds, and large financial institutions recognize the potential of aligning their portfolios with social values ​​and goals. Examples of impact investing include financing for renewable energy, affordable housing, global health, and education. However, impact investing faces challenges such as measuring social and environmental impact, reconciling financial returns and positive impact, and creating clear standards and frameworks to guide investors. Despite these challenges, impact investing is redefining the role of capital in global development and opening up new opportunities for philanthropy and the private sector to contribute to a more sustainable and equitable future.

11-12.text: Cleantech, also known as cleantech, is at the forefront of the transition to a sustainable economy, offering innovative solutions to reduce the environmental impact of human activity. Cleantech encompasses a wide range of technologies, from renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, to energy efficiency, advanced recycling, and electric mobility. These technologies not only help mitigate climate change, but also create economic opportunities by creating new green jobs and developing sustainable industries. However, cleantech adoption faces challenges such as initial funding, competition with lower-cost traditional technologies, and the need for government policies and incentives to support innovation and implementation. As the demand for sustainable solutions grows, cleantech will play a crucial role in building a greener, more resilient future, benefiting both the environment and the economy.

11-13.text: Humanitarian aid plays a vital role in responding to global crises such as armed conflicts, natural disasters, and public health emergencies. International humanitarian organizations, NGOs, and government agencies work together to provide immediate assistance, such as food, water, shelter, and medical care, to affected populations. In addition, humanitarian aid also includes reconstruction and resilience efforts, helping communities recover and prepare for future crises. However, delivering humanitarian aid faces significant challenges, such as access to conflict areas, the safety of humanitarian workers, and effective coordination among multiple actors. Technological innovation, such as the use of drones to deliver supplies and the development of mobile apps for crisis monitoring, is helping to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of humanitarian operations. Humanitarian aid is a crucial component of the global response to crises, saving lives and providing hope and dignity to people in times of extreme need.

11-14.text: Urban resilience is the ability of cities to withstand, adapt to, and recover from shocks and stresses, such as natural disasters, climate change, economic and social crises. Building urban resilience involves planning and implementing robust and adaptable infrastructure, fostering inclusive communities, and strengthening social support networks. Resilient cities are designed to proactively address challenges by integrating solutions such as green infrastructure, flexible transportation systems, and buildings that can withstand extreme weather events. In addition, urban resilience includes the ability to respond quickly to crises such as pandemics and to adapt to long-term changes such as sea level rise. Urban resilience requires an integrated and collaborative approach, involving local governments, businesses, NGOs, and citizens. As cities face increasing challenges in the 21st century, building urban resilience will be essential to ensuring the safety, prosperity, and quality of life of their inhabitants.

11-15.text: Global health challenges are vast and complex, ranging from infectious diseases such as HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria to the rise of chronic non-communicable diseases such as diabetes, cancer and heart disease. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the fragility of health systems worldwide and the urgent need to strengthen global capacity to respond to public health emergencies. In addition, issues such as antimicrobial resistance, lack of access to health care in low-income countries and health inequalities remain major challenges. Addressing these challenges requires a coordinated global effort that includes strengthening health systems, innovating in research and development, and promoting public health policies that address the social determinants of health. International collaboration, investment in health infrastructure and a commitment to health equity are key to overcoming global health challenges and improving the well-being of populations worldwide.

11-16.text: Ethical investing, also known as socially responsible investing (SRI), is an approach that considers social, environmental and governance impacts when making investment decisions. Ethical investors seek to support companies and projects that promote sustainable practices, respect human rights and operate with transparency and accountability. This type of investing is growing in popularity as more investors recognise that ethical business practices can lead to strong, long-term financial performance. Examples of ethical investing include funds that exclude companies involved in fossil fuels, armaments or child labour, and that favour those that lead in renewable energy, healthcare and education. However, ethical investing also faces challenges, such as defining clear criteria, measuring impact and preventing greenwashing, where companies exaggerate their sustainability credentials. Ethical investing represents a significant shift in the way capital is allocated, encouraging more responsible and sustainable business practices.

11-17.text: The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), established in 2015, are a set of 17 interconnected goals that aim to end poverty, protect the planet and ensure prosperity for all by 2030. The SDGs address pressing global issues such as hunger, health, education, gender equality, clean water and sanitation, affordable and sustainable energy, economic growth, reduced inequalities, climate action, peace and justice, among others. Implementing the SDGs requires the collaboration of governments, the private sector, civil society and citizens around the world. While significant progress has been made in several areas, many challenges remain, such as resource inequality between countries, lack of adequate financing, and political and cultural barriers. The SDGs provide a comprehensive framework for sustainable development, encouraging coordinated and ambitious action to create a more just, safe and sustainable future for all.

11-18.text: Cybersecurity innovation is crucial to protecting individuals, businesses, and governments from the growing threats of the digital world, such as hacking, malware, ransomware, and cyber espionage. Emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, blockchain, and advanced encryption are being developed to strengthen cyber defenses and ensure data security. In addition, cybersecurity education and awareness of digital best practices are becoming increasingly important as threats become more sophisticated and cyberattacks more frequent. Cybersecurity innovation also involves building systems for rapid incident detection and response, protecting critical infrastructure such as energy and transportation, and ensuring the privacy of personal data. However, cybersecurity innovation faces challenges such as rapidly evolving threats, a shortage of skilled professionals, and the need for international collaboration to combat cybercrime. Cybersecurity is a dynamic and constantly evolving field that is essential to protecting the digital economy and society as a whole.

11-19.text: Blockchain governance is an emerging topic as the technology expands beyond cryptocurrencies to impact industries such as finance, supply chain, healthcare, and corporate governance. Blockchain governance refers to the rules, processes, and frameworks that regulate how blockchain networks are operated, updated, and maintained. Unlike traditional systems, blockchain governance can be decentralized, allowing network participants to have a say in decisions such as protocol changes or dispute resolution. However, blockchain governance also faces challenges such as coordinating across multiple stakeholders, preventing centralization of power in a few hands, and managing security issues. Creating effective and transparent governance models is crucial to the long-term success of blockchain networks and ensuring that this technology is used ethically and efficiently. Blockchain governance is shaping the future of decentralized technologies and has the potential to transform the way organizations and societies operate.

11-20.text: The future of work is being redefined by technological advances, demographic shifts and new expectations of workers. Automation, artificial intelligence, remote working and the gig economy are transforming how people work, where they work and the type of work they do. On the one hand, these changes can increase productivity, make working hours more flexible and create new economic opportunities. On the other hand, they also raise concerns about job security, income inequality, social protection and the need for workers to reskill. Companies and governments are facing the challenge of adapting labour market policies and education systems to prepare workers for the new realities of the labour market. Creating an inclusive, safe and sustainable workplace that balances the needs of workers with the demands of the digital economy is critical to the future of work. Successfully adapting to the future of work requires innovation, collaboration and a human-centred approach to ensure that the benefits of change are broadly shared.

11-21.text: Smart agriculture, or digital agriculture, is revolutionizing food production, using technologies such as the Internet of Things (IoT), artificial intelligence, and big data to improve the efficiency, productivity, and sustainability of farming operations. Soil sensors, drones, agricultural robots, and climate monitoring systems enable farmers to make data-driven decisions, optimizing the use of resources such as water, fertilizers, and energy. Smart agriculture not only increases crop yields but also reduces environmental impact by promoting more sustainable farming practices. In addition, digital connectivity is facilitating farmers’ access to markets, information, and finance, especially in rural and remote areas. However, the adoption of smart agriculture faces challenges, such as the cost of technologies, the need for farmer training, and the integration of innovations in different regional contexts. Smart agriculture represents a significant evolution in the agricultural sector, with the potential to feed a growing global population in a sustainable and resilient way.

11-22.text: Urban renewal is the process of revitalizing degraded or underutilized areas of cities, with the aim of improving the quality of life of residents, promoting economic development, and protecting cultural heritage. Urban renewal projects can include the revitalization of historic buildings, the creation of green public spaces, the modernization of infrastructure, and the promotion of affordable housing. In addition, urban renewal often seeks to involve local communities in planning and implementation, ensuring that benefits are widely distributed and that the needs of residents are met. However, urban renewal can also face challenges, such as gentrification, which can displace low-income populations, and resistance to change. To be successful, urban renewal must balance economic development with social inclusion and environmental sustainability, creating more vibrant, livable, and resilient cities.

11-23.text: Mental health technology is evolving rapidly, providing new tools for diagnosis, treatment, and emotional support. Mobile apps, digital therapeutics, telepsychology platforms, and wearable devices are making access to mental health care more convenient and accessible for millions of people around the world. These technologies allow individuals to monitor their symptoms, practice self-care techniques, and access therapeutic support in a discreet and personalized way. In addition, artificial intelligence is being used to develop therapeutic chatbots and to analyze mental health data, providing insights that can improve the quality of care. However, the adoption of mental health technology also raises questions about privacy, data security, and the effectiveness of digital interventions. It is crucial that these tools are integrated into health systems in an ethical manner and are supported by scientific evidence to ensure that they deliver real benefits to users. Mental health technology has the potential to transform the way mental health is managed and treated, promoting greater access, efficiency, and personalization of care.

11-24.text: Digital marketing is revolutionizing the way businesses connect with their customers, using digital technologies to reach and engage audiences in more effective and personalized ways. Platforms such as social media, search engines, email marketing, and online advertising allow businesses to precisely target their ads, measure results in real time, and adjust their strategies based on data. In addition, digital marketing is evolving with the use of artificial intelligence, which enables campaign automation, personalization at scale, and predictive analysis of consumer behavior. However, digital marketing also faces challenges such as data privacy, increasing competition for attention, and the need to adapt to rapidly changing platform algorithms. To be successful in digital marketing, businesses need to develop integrated, customer-centric, and data-driven strategies that can adapt to emerging trends and stay relevant in an ever-evolving marketplace.

11-25.text: Mitigating global warming is a global priority, focused on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and limiting the increase in global average temperature. Mitigation efforts include transitioning to renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, increasing energy efficiency, protecting forests and other carbon sinks, and promoting sustainable agricultural and land-use practices. Mitigation also involves developing and deploying carbon capture and storage technologies, which can remove CO2 from the atmosphere. In addition, public policies such as carbon taxes, clean energy subsidies, and international agreements such as the Paris Agreement are key to driving climate action. However, mitigating global warming faces significant challenges, including political resistance, dependence on fossil fuels, and the need for financing and innovation. Effective mitigation is essential to avoid the most severe impacts of climate change and ensure a sustainable future for the planet.

11-26.text: Sustainable tourism is gaining prominence as an approach that seeks to balance the needs of tourists with the protection of the environment and the well-being of local communities. Sustainable tourism promotes practices that minimize environmental impact, such as reducing the consumption of natural resources, responsible waste management, and the preservation of sensitive ecosystems. In addition, sustainable tourism values ​​local culture, involving communities in tourism development, and ensuring that economic benefits are widely distributed. Examples of sustainable tourism include ecotourism, community-based tourism, and travel that respects the carrying capacity of destinations. However, sustainable tourism faces challenges such as the growth of mass tourism, the need for regulation, and educating tourists about responsible practices. Promoting sustainable tourism is essential to ensure that future generations can continue to enjoy tourism destinations while protecting the planet’s natural and cultural heritage.

11-27.text: Quantum technology is at the forefront of scientific innovation, with the potential to transform areas such as computing, cryptography, communications, and sensing. Quantum computers, which use qubits instead of traditional bits, promise to perform calculations at unparalleled speeds, solving complex problems that are beyond the capabilities of classical computers. Furthermore, quantum cryptography offers unprecedented data security, based on the principles of quantum mechanics, which can protect communications against cyberattacks. Quantum communications, using quantum entanglement, have the potential to revolutionize information transmission by providing tamper-proof communication channels. However, the development of quantum technology faces significant challenges, such as building stable hardware and scaling quantum systems. As quantum technology advances, it promises to open new frontiers in science and technology, with profound implications for security, the economy, and society.

11-28.text: Mental health support is a crucial part of overall wellbeing, recognizing that mental health is just as important as physical health. Mental health support can include a wide range of services, from individual and group therapy to workplace wellness programs, online counseling, and emotional support lines. Accessibility to mental health support is critical, especially in areas where health services are limited or stigmatized. Furthermore, mental health support should be culturally sensitive and tailored to the specific needs of different populations, such as children, older adults, ethnic minorities, and LGBTQ+ people. Promoting mental health in the workplace, for example, can include work-life balance policies, stress management support, and initiatives to reduce stigma. Strengthening mental health support is essential to improving quality of life, increasing productivity, and fostering resilience in the face of life’s challenges.

11-29.text: Reducing global poverty remains one of the greatest challenges of the 21st century, with millions of people living in extreme poverty, lacking access to basic necessities such as food, clean water, education and health care. Efforts to reduce global poverty include economic development programs, access to microcredit, universal education, gender equality and strengthening social safety nets. Furthermore, poverty eradication is intrinsically linked to sustainable development, which aims to create conditions for all people to thrive without compromising the planet’s natural resources. International organizations, governments and NGOs are working together to achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), which include the eradication of poverty by 2030. However, challenges such as economic inequality, conflict and climate change continue to complicate efforts to reduce global poverty. Continued commitment to poverty reduction is essential to promote social justice, global stability and human development.

11-30.text: Smart grids are transforming the way electricity is generated, distributed and consumed, making the energy system more efficient, resilient and sustainable. Smart grids use digital technologies to monitor and manage electricity flows in real time, integrating renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, and enabling active participation by consumers, who can generate and store their own energy. In addition, smart grids make it easier to detect and correct faults, optimize energy consumption and reduce transmission losses. However, implementing smart grids faces challenges, such as the need to modernize existing infrastructure, protect the system against cyberattacks and ensure the privacy of consumer data. Smart grids are an essential component of the transition to a low-carbon economy, supporting sustainable growth and energy security.

12-1.text: Global food security is a critical challenge in the 21st century, with a growing population, climate change, and economic crises putting pressure on food production and distribution. Food security involves ensuring that all people have access to sufficient, safe, and nutritious food, and that food systems are resilient to shocks and stresses. Solutions to food security include developing sustainable agricultural practices, promoting healthy diets, reducing food waste, and strengthening supply chains. Furthermore, food security is closely linked to equity, as the most vulnerable populations, such as the poor and smallholder farmers, are often the most affected by food insecurity. International collaboration, technological innovation, and effective public policies are essential to address food security challenges and ensure that everyone has access to enough food for a healthy and productive life.

12-2.text: Sustainable urban development is essential to address the challenges of rapid urbanization, such as pressure on natural resources, social inequality, and climate change. Sustainable cities are planned and managed in a way that balances economic growth, social inclusion, and environmental protection. Sustainable urban development practices include the construction of energy-efficient buildings, the promotion of public transport and active mobility, the creation of green spaces, and effective waste management. In addition, sustainable urban planning involves the participation of local communities in the decision-making process, ensuring that development meets the needs of all residents. Examples of sustainable urban development can be seen in cities such as Copenhagen, Singapore, and Curitiba, which have adopted innovative policies to improve quality of life and reduce their ecological footprint. Sustainable urban development is essential to creating resilient and livable cities that can withstand the challenges of the 21st century and beyond.

12-3.text: Social inclusion is a central objective for the development of equitable and just societies, ensuring that all people, regardless of their origin, gender, ethnicity, or socioeconomic status, have access to the same opportunities and can participate fully in economic, social, and political life. Efforts to promote social inclusion include affirmative action policies, the promotion of gender equality, combating racism and discrimination, and strengthening social safety nets. Social inclusion also involves ensuring equal access to basic services, such as education, health, and housing, and creating environments that value diversity and promote social cohesion. Digital inclusion, which aims to ensure that everyone has access to information and communication technologies, is increasingly important in an increasingly connected world. Promoting social inclusion is essential to reducing inequalities, strengthening democracy, and building more resilient and harmonious societies.

12-4.text: The global refugee crisis is one of the most pressing humanitarian issues of our time, with millions of people forced to flee their countries due to conflict, persecution, natural disasters and other crises. Refugees face extreme challenges, including loss of homes, separation from families, lack of access to basic services and the risk of exploitation and abuse. The global response to the refugee crisis involves protecting refugees’ rights, providing humanitarian assistance such as food, water, shelter and medical care, and finding durable solutions such as local integration, resettlement in third countries or safe voluntary repatriation. However, the refugee crisis also raises complex political issues, such as burden-sharing between countries, border security and combating xenophobia and racism. International collaboration and respect for human rights are essential to addressing the refugee crisis and providing protection and dignity to forcibly displaced people.

12-5.text: Innovation in renewable energy is accelerating the transition to a more sustainable energy system, offering technological solutions to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and mitigate climate change. New technologies such as high-efficiency solar panels, offshore wind turbines, long-duration battery storage and green hydrogen are expanding the possibilities for generating and storing clean energy. In addition, digitalization and smart grids are improving the integration of renewable energy into the electricity grid, enabling more efficient and flexible energy management. Innovation in renewable energy is also creating economic opportunities, generating green jobs and driving the development of new industries. However, the energy transition faces challenges such as the need for infrastructure investment, adapting public policies and ensuring energy justice for all communities. Continuous innovation is crucial to accelerate the transition to a sustainable energy future and achieve global carbon reduction targets.

12-6.text: The gig economy, characterized by temporary work and freelance work, is growing rapidly, driven by digitalization and the demand for flexible work. Digital platforms such as Uber, Airbnb, and Upwork are at the heart of this economy, connecting workers with consumers and companies looking for temporary services. The gig economy offers advantages such as the flexibility for workers to choose when and where to work, and for companies, the ability to quickly scale their workforce according to demand. However, the gig economy also raises questions about job security, social protection, and workers’ rights. Many gig workers face uncertain income, lack of benefits such as health insurance and retirement, and the absence of protection against arbitrary dismissal. As the gig economy continues to grow, governments and unions are exploring ways to regulate and protect workers’ rights, ensuring that flexibility does not come at the expense of security and well-being.

12-7.text: Smart homes are revolutionizing the concept of living, integrating technology and design to create more efficient, comfortable and sustainable spaces. Smart homes use internet-connected devices such as smart thermostats, automated lighting systems, electronic locks and virtual assistants, which allow residents to control various aspects of their homes remotely, via smartphones or voice commands. In addition to offering convenience and personalization, smart homes can also improve energy efficiency, reduce maintenance costs and increase security. However, increasing connectivity also brings challenges, such as data privacy, cybersecurity and the accessibility of these technologies to different segments of the population. As technology advances, smart homes have the potential to transform the way we live, creating homes that are more connected, sustainable and adaptable to the needs of residents.

12-8.text: Climate activism is becoming a powerful force in the fight against climate change, with global movements pushing governments, businesses and society to take urgent action to reduce carbon emissions and protect the environment. Movements such as the youth-led Fridays for Future and the direct-action Extinction Rebellion have gained international prominence, mobilizing millions of people in protests and campaigns. Climate activism is also raising public awareness of the climate crisis and demanding policy changes, such as the transition to renewable energy, the protection of forests and the adoption of sustainable agricultural practices. However, climate activism faces challenges, including political resistance, the influence of the fossil fuel industry and the need to build broad and inclusive coalitions. Climate activism is a crucial component of the global response to climate change, playing an essential role in mobilizing action and advancing climate justice.

12-9.text: Sustainable fashion is becoming a growing trend as consumers and businesses seek to reduce the environmental and social impact of the fashion industry. Sustainable fashion involves the use of eco-friendly materials such as organic cotton, recycled fibers, and biodegradable fabrics, as well as production practices that minimize the use of water, energy, and chemicals. Sustainable fashion also promotes the longevity of clothing by encouraging high-quality design, repair, and reuse, rather than the fast fashion model that encourages rapid consumption and disposal. Additionally, supply chain transparency and fair trade are key aspects of sustainable fashion, ensuring that workers are treated fairly and environmental impacts are minimized. While sustainable fashion still faces challenges, such as cost and the need for changes in consumer behavior, it represents an important step towards a more responsible and conscious fashion industry.

12-10.text: Climate change mitigation involves a range of global actions and strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and limit global warming to safe levels. Key approaches to mitigation include transitioning to renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, promoting energy efficiency, protecting and restoring forests, and developing carbon capture and storage technologies. In addition, public policies such as carbon taxes, clean energy subsidies, and international agreements are essential to drive climate action. Climate change mitigation also requires collaboration between governments, businesses, NGOs, and citizens, as well as significant investments in infrastructure and innovation. Successful climate mitigation is crucial to avoiding the most severe impacts of climate change and ensuring a sustainable future for future generations.

12-11.text: Mental health initiatives are gaining prominence globally as awareness grows about the need for appropriate support and treatment for conditions such as depression, anxiety, and stress disorders. These initiatives include awareness campaigns, prevention programs, counseling and therapy services, and public health policies that aim to integrate mental health into primary health care. In addition, there is a growing focus on addressing the stigma associated with mental health, which often prevents people from seeking help. Mental health initiatives are also expanding to include workplace wellness, with companies implementing support programs and resources for their employees. However, challenges remain, such as the lack of access to mental health services in low-income regions, the shortage of qualified professionals, and the need for sustainable funding. Strengthening mental health initiatives is essential to improving people’s quality of life and promoting healthier, more resilient societies.

12-12.text: Waste management is an environmental and public health challenge that requires innovative and sustainable solutions to deal with the growing volume of waste generated by modern society. Waste management practices include source reduction, recycling, composting and energy recovery from waste, as well as proper treatment and final disposal in controlled landfills. Effective waste management is essential to minimize negative impacts on the environment, such as soil, water and air pollution, as well as to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Initiatives such as the circular economy, which aims to keep resources in use for as long as possible and minimize waste, are gaining momentum as part of an integrated approach to waste management. However, challenges such as lack of adequate infrastructure, public awareness and the need for stronger policies still need to be overcome to achieve truly sustainable waste management.

12-13.text: Digital education is transforming the way knowledge is transmitted and acquired, using technologies such as online learning platforms, artificial intelligence and virtual reality to create more accessible, interactive and personalized educational experiences. Digital learning enables students from anywhere in the world to access high-quality courses and resources, often for free or at low cost, breaking down geographical and economic barriers. In addition, digital education facilitates lifelong learning, allowing individuals to acquire new skills and adapt to changing job markets. However, the adoption of digital education also faces challenges, such as inequality in access to technology, the need for teacher training and ensuring that digital learning is inclusive and equitable. As digital education continues to evolve, it promises to play a crucial role in preparing future generations for the challenges and opportunities of the 21st century.

12-14.text: The circular economy is an economic model that aims to eliminate waste and maximize the efficient use of resources by promoting the recycling, reuse and regeneration of materials throughout their life cycles. Unlike the traditional linear model of ‘take, make, dispose’, the circular economy seeks to create closed systems in which waste is minimized and products and materials retain their value for longer. Examples of circular economy practices include designing products for durability and repairability, recovering end-of-life materials, and developing new service-based business models such as rental and sharing. The transition to a circular economy requires collaboration between governments, businesses and consumers, as well as policies that encourage innovation and sustainability. The circular economy is seen as a solution to environmental challenges such as resource scarcity and pollution, and as an economic opportunity for creating green jobs and sustainable development.

12-15.text: Healthcare innovations are revolutionizing medicine, offering new ways to prevent, diagnose, and treat disease. Emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, biotechnology, telemedicine, and genomics are enabling a more personalized and effective approach to health management. For example, artificial intelligence can analyze large volumes of medical data to identify patterns and predict outcomes, while biotechnology is being used to develop new gene therapies and precision medicines. In addition, telemedicine is expanding access to healthcare, especially in rural and isolated areas, by allowing patients to consult with doctors remotely. However, these innovations also raise ethical and practical issues, such as data privacy, the cost of advanced treatments, and equitable access to new technologies. The continued advancement of healthcare innovations promises to transform the way we care for health and treat disease, but it requires a balanced approach to ensure that the benefits are broadly shared.

12-16.text: Environmental education is essential to raise awareness of environmental issues and empower people to take action for sustainability. Environmental education encompasses a wide range of activities, from integrating environmental issues into school curricula to public awareness programs, community workshops and media campaigns. The goal of environmental education is not only to inform, but also to inspire behavior change by promoting sustainable practices such as water conservation, waste reduction and biodiversity protection. Furthermore, environmental education can empower people to participate in environmentally-related decision-making processes, influencing public policies and local initiatives. Environmental education is essential to building a more conscious and responsible society, capable of addressing global environmental challenges and ensuring a sustainable future for future generations.

12-17.text: Social innovation is emerging as a creative and effective response to the social, environmental, and economic challenges faced by communities around the world. Social innovation refers to the development and implementation of new ideas, models, and practices that address social needs more effectively and sustainably than traditional solutions. Examples include microfinance to support small entrepreneurs in developing countries, inclusive education programs for children with special needs, and community recycling initiatives that create jobs and reduce waste. Social innovation is often driven by partnerships between governments, NGOs, businesses, and civil society, and can involve the use of technology, design thinking, and community participation to create solutions that are scalable and replicable. Fostering social innovation is essential to addressing the challenges of the 21st century by promoting inclusion, equity, and sustainability in all spheres of life.

12-18.text: Public health is a critical area that aims to protect and improve the health of populations through organized and informed efforts, including disease prevention, health promotion, and response to health emergencies. Public health encompasses a wide range of activities, from vaccination campaigns and health education programs to the implementation of policies that ensure food security and access to quality health care. In addition, public health is increasingly focused on addressing the social determinants of health, such as poverty, inequality, and the environment, which affect the health of populations across the board. International collaboration is essential to address global public health challenges such as pandemics, antimicrobial resistance, and climate change. Strengthening public health systems is critical to ensuring that all people can live healthy and productive lives, regardless of their location or socioeconomic status.

12-19.text: Financial inclusion is a key sustainable development goal, aiming to ensure that all people, especially the most vulnerable, have access to affordable, safe and useful financial services. Financial inclusion enables individuals and businesses to participate fully in the economy, fostering economic growth, poverty reduction and financial resilience. Efforts to promote financial inclusion include expanding access to bank accounts, credit, insurance and digital payment services, especially in rural areas and among low-income populations. Innovation in financial technology (fintech), such as mobile payments and microfinance platforms, is playing a crucial role in promoting financial inclusion by enabling people previously excluded from the formal financial system to access these services. However, challenges remain, such as the need for financial literacy, consumer protection and effective regulation to ensure that financial inclusion is equitable and sustainable.

12-20.text: Digital ethics are becoming increasingly important as technology permeates every aspect of modern life, raising questions about privacy, security, transparency and accountability. Digital ethics refers to the principles and values ​​that guide the responsible and fair use of digital technology, ensuring that it benefits society without causing harm or injustice. Critical issues in digital ethics include the use of personal data, AI-powered decision-making, cybersecurity, digital inclusion and the environmental impact of technology. Businesses, governments and civil society organisations are developing codes of conduct, regulations and educational initiatives to promote digital ethics and protect the rights of individuals in an increasingly connected world. Promoting digital ethics is essential to building a fair, equitable and sustainable digital society, where technological innovation is aligned with fundamental human values.

12-21.text: The clean energy transition is one of the key global strategies to combat climate change, reduce pollution, and promote sustainability. Clean energy includes renewable sources such as solar, wind, hydropower, and biomass that produce electricity without emitting greenhouse gases. The clean energy transition involves the gradual replacement of fossil fuels with these renewable sources in all sectors of the economy, from electricity generation to transportation and industry. In addition, energy efficiency and the development of new technologies such as energy storage batteries and green hydrogen are essential components of this transition. The clean energy transition also offers economic opportunities such as the creation of green jobs, technological innovation, and improved energy security. However, the transition faces challenges such as initial financing, resistance from traditional industries, and the need for robust public policies to support the change. The clean energy transition is essential to achieving a sustainable future and avoiding the catastrophic impacts of climate change.

12-22.text: The future of artificial intelligence (AI) is one of the most debated and speculated issues in science and technology. As AI continues to evolve, it has the potential to radically transform the way we live, work, and interact. AI is already being used to automate routine tasks, improve medical diagnoses, optimize supply chains, and personalize consumer experiences. However, the future of AI also raises ethical and social issues, such as the impact on employment, data privacy, bias in algorithms, and the possibility of runaway superintelligences. Responsible AI development, which includes transparency, fairness, and accountability, is essential to ensure that the benefits of AI are broadly shared and that the risks are mitigated. The future of AI promises to bring exciting and challenging innovations that will shape society in the coming decades in ways that are difficult to predict.

12-23.text: Smart cities are emerging as an innovative solution to address the urban challenges of the 21st century, using advanced technology to improve efficiency, sustainability and quality of life in urban areas. Smart cities integrate sensors, connected devices and digital platforms to manage resources, monitor traffic, optimize energy consumption and improve public services. Examples include smart street lighting that reduces energy consumption, automated public transport systems that improve urban mobility and water distribution networks that detect and correct leaks. In addition, smart cities promote citizen participation, allowing residents to interact with city administration and contribute to the decision-making process. However, the implementation of smart cities also faces challenges, such as data privacy, cybersecurity and social inclusion. The transition to smart cities requires a collaborative approach between governments, businesses and citizens, ensuring that technology is used for the benefit of all and contributes to sustainable urban development.

12-24.text: The French Revolution of 1848 was part of a wave of revolutions that swept Europe that year, known as the Revolutions of 1848 or the Spring of Nations. In France, the revolt was motivated by dissatisfaction with the government of King Louis Philippe, who represented the interests of the bourgeoisie at the expense of the working classes. The revolution began with protests and barricades in Paris, leading to the abdication of the king and the proclamation of the Second Republic. However, the Republic soon faced internal divisions between moderate liberals and radical socialists, culminating in repression and the establishment of the authoritarian presidency of Louis-Napoleon Bonaparte, who would later become Emperor Napoleon III.

12-25.text: The Meiji Restoration, which took place in 1868, was a turning point in Japanese history, marking the country's transition from an isolated, feudal country to a modern, industrialized power. The central event of the Restoration was the overthrow of the Tokugawa shogunate and the restoration of imperial power under Emperor Meiji. Under Meiji's leadership, Japan underwent radical reforms in all spheres of society, including military modernization, the development of an industrial economy, and the adoption of a Western educational system. These changes transformed Japan into a regional power and paved the way for its rise as a major player on the international stage, culminating in the victory over Russia in the Russo-Japanese War (1904–1905).

12-26.text: The Italian Unification, also known as the Risorgimento, was the process of unification of the various independent states of the Italian Peninsula into a single Kingdom of Italy, which was completed in 1871. The movement for unification was driven by figures such as Giuseppe Mazzini, Giuseppe Garibaldi, and the statesman Count of Cavour. Mazzini was an early advocate of a unified and republican Italy, while Garibaldi led decisive military campaigns, such as the Expedition of the Thousand, which conquered the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies. Cavour, as Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Sardinia, used diplomacy to gain the support of France and secure the annexation of territories. The unification culminated in the capture of Rome, which became the capital of the new Kingdom of Italy.

12-27.text: The Berlin Conference, held between 1884 and 1885, was a crucial event in the process of colonization of Africa by European powers. Convened by German Chancellor Otto von Bismarck, the conference aimed to settle the dispute between European countries over the possession of African territories and to avoid direct conflicts between them. The decisions taken at the conference resulted in the division of the African continent into colonies controlled by powers such as Great Britain, France, Germany and Belgium, often disregarding existing ethnic and cultural boundaries. The Berlin Conference marked the beginning of the era of Imperialism in Africa, which had profound and lasting consequences for the continent, including economic exploitation, the imposition of European cultures and anti-colonial resistance.

12-28.text: The Cuban Missile Crisis, which occurred in October 1962, was one of the most tense moments of the Cold War, and nearly led to a nuclear confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union. The crisis began when the United States discovered that the Soviet Union was installing nuclear missiles in Cuba, just 90 miles from the U.S. coast. President John F. Kennedy ordered a naval blockade of Cuba and demanded the removal of the missiles. After 13 days of intense negotiations, Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev agreed to remove the missiles in exchange for a U.S. promise not to invade Cuba and to remove U.S. missiles from Turkey. The crisis resulted in a temporary easing of tensions, but it also demonstrated the imminent threat of nuclear war during the Cold War.

12-29.text: The end of apartheid in South Africa was one of the most significant events of the late 20th century, marking the fall of one of the most notorious regimes of racial segregation. Officially established in 1948, apartheid was a system of racial discrimination that segregated the South African population on the basis of ethnicity and imposed severe restrictions on the rights of the black majority. The struggle against apartheid was led by figures such as Nelson Mandela and the African National Congress (ANC), who faced decades of repression. After intense domestic and international pressure, the South African government, under the leadership of F.W. de Klerk, began negotiations that led to the end of apartheid and the first multiracial elections in 1994, in which Mandela was elected president.

12-30.text: The fall of the Berlin Wall on 9 November 1989 marked the end of an era and was a powerful symbol of the collapse of the Iron Curtain and the end of the Cold War. The wall, erected in 1961 by East Germany to prevent its citizens from fleeing to the West, became an icon of the division between the communist East and the capitalist West. In 1989, a wave of pro-democracy protests swept the Eastern Bloc, and the East German government, under pressure for political and social change, announced the opening of its borders. Thousands of Berliners from both East and West gathered to tear down the wall, celebrating the reunification of Germany. The fall of the Berlin Wall accelerated the collapse of the Soviet Bloc and the transition of many Eastern European countries to democracy and a market economy.

12-31.text: The conquest of space marked an era of technological innovation and global competition during the Cold War. One of the most significant moments was on July 20, 1969, when the United States' Apollo 11 mission landed the first humans on the Moon. NASA astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the lunar surface, while Michael Collins remained in orbit. The event was broadcast live to millions of people around the world and symbolized the culmination of the space race between the United States and the Soviet Union. Armstrong's iconic phrase, "That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind," became a landmark of human exploration and technological prowess. The success of Apollo 11 cemented the United States' role as a leader in space exploration and paved the way for future space exploration missions.
